title: How to Create Two Networks from One Connection

steps.headline: Hit the Windows key.
steps.description: The Windows key will have the Windows logo on it and it can be located on the bottom left side of most keyboards.

steps.headline: Open Settings.
steps.description: Settings can be located by either searching for “settings” in the search bar or clicking the settings icon on the bottom left corner.

steps.headline: Locate and open Mobile hotspot.
steps.description: This will be located in bottom left hand corner above data usage.

steps.headline: Edit the network name and password.
steps.description: Click on the edit button and choose a name and password of your liking.

steps.headline: Turn on Mobile hotspot.
steps.description: Turn on hotspot if it is not already on.

methods.name: Creating Two Networks Using Two Routers

steps.headline: Connect primary (better) router to power.
steps.description: Connect the power adapter to a reliable outlet and then connect it to your primary router.

steps.headline: Connect primary router to internet service provider.
steps.description: Locate ISP cable and plug it into the primary router. The ISP cable will be coaxial cable and needs to be plugged into a coaxial port.

steps.headline: Connect secondary router to power.
steps.description: Connect the power adapter to a reliable outlet and then connect it to your secondary router.

steps.headline: Connect secondary router to primary router.
steps.description:
This can be done using Ethernet or Wi-Fi. The steps vary a little depending on your choice. Ethernet:
Use the Ethernet cable to connect both routers using the Ethernet port. Connect one end of the Ethernet cable into to the Ethernet port of the primary router and the other end into the Ethernet port of the secondary router. Wi-Fi:
Go to secondary router’s settings page and Login with credentials. Check the back or the bottom of your router for the address. The address might either be a link or a series of numbers. For example, http://login.net or 192.168.x.x. In most cases, the username and password can be found next to the address information. If username and password are not present, try “admin” for the username and “password” for the password. If this does not work contact ISP. Locate and enter the secondary router's settings page. Find the setup/settings page for your secondary router. Set up the secondary router. Click on the range extender button on the settings page in your secondary router. Connect the secondary router. Search and connect the secondary router to the already existing network.

steps.headline: Edit privacy settings.
steps.description: Change the network name and password for the secondary connection to your desired name and password.

tyn: Laptop or tablet running Windows 8.1 or up (32 bit or 64 bit)
Device with internet access (can be a laptop)
text:
Creating Two Networks Using Hotspot Hit the Windows key. The Windows key will have the Windows logo on it and it can be located on the bottom left side of most keyboards. Open Settings. Settings can be located by either searching for “settings” in the search bar or clicking the settings icon on the bottom left corner. Open Network & Internet. It will have globe icon. Locate and open Mobile hotspot. This will be located in bottom left hand corner above data usage. Edit the network name and password. Click on the edit button and choose a name and password of your liking. Turn on Mobile hotspot. Turn on hotspot if it is not already on. Creating Two Networks Using Two Routers Connect primary (better) router to power. Connect the power adapter to a reliable outlet and then connect it to your primary router. Connect primary router to internet service provider. Locate ISP cable and plug it into the primary router. The ISP cable will be coaxial cable and needs to be plugged into a coaxial port. Connect secondary router to power. Connect the power adapter to a reliable outlet and then connect it to your secondary router. Connect secondary router to primary router. This can be done using Ethernet or Wi-Fi. The steps vary a little depending on your choice. Ethernet:
Use the Ethernet cable to connect both routers using the Ethernet port. Connect one end of the Ethernet cable into to the Ethernet port of the primary router and the other end into the Ethernet port of the secondary router. Wi-Fi:
Go to secondary router’s settings page and Login with credentials. Check the back or the bottom of your router for the address. The address might either be a link or a series of numbers. For example, http://login.net or 192.168.x.x. In most cases, the username and password can be found next to the address information. If username and password are not present, try “admin” for the username and “password” for the password. If this does not work contact ISP. Locate and enter the secondary router's settings page. Find the setup/settings page for your secondary router. Set up the secondary router. Click on the range extender button on the settings page in your secondary router. Connect the secondary router. Search and connect the secondary router to the already existing network. Edit privacy settings. Change the network name and password for the secondary connection to your desired name and password.
sentences: Creating Two Networks Using Hotspot Hit the Windows key.
The Windows key will have the Windows logo on it and it can be located on the bottom left side of most keyboards.
Open Settings.
Settings can be located by either searching for “settings” in the search bar or clicking the settings icon on the bottom left corner.
Open Network & Internet.
It will have globe icon.
Locate and open Mobile hotspot.
This will be located in bottom left hand corner above data usage.
Edit the network name and password.
Click on the edit button and choose a name and password of your liking.
Turn on Mobile hotspot.
Turn on hotspot if it is not already on.
Creating Two Networks Using Two Routers Connect primary (better) router to power.
Connect the power adapter to a reliable outlet and then connect it to your primary router.
Connect primary router to internet service provider.
Locate ISP cable and plug it into the primary router.
The ISP cable will be coaxial cable and needs to be plugged into a coaxial port.
Connect secondary router to power.
Connect the power adapter to a reliable outlet and then connect it to your secondary router.
Connect secondary router to primary router.
This can be done using Ethernet or Wi-Fi.
The steps vary a little depending on your choice.

Ethernet:
Use the Ethernet cable to connect both routers using the Ethernet port.
Connect one end of the Ethernet cable into to the Ethernet port of the primary router and the other end into the Ethernet port of the secondary router.

Wi-Fi:
Go to secondary router’s settings page and Login with credentials.
Check the back or the bottom of your router for the address.
The address might either be a link or a series of numbers.
For example, http://login.net or 192.168.x.x.
In most cases, the username and password can be found next to the address information.
If username and password are not present, try “admin” for the username and “password” for the password.
If this does not work contact ISP.
Locate and enter the secondary router's settings page.
Find the setup/settings page for your secondary router.
Set up the secondary router.
Click on the range extender button on the settings page in your secondary router.
Connect the secondary router.
Search and connect the secondary router to the already existing network.
Edit privacy settings.
Change the network name and password for the secondary connection to your desired name and password.
